dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we've been looking at this, uh, fascinating piece about what the post-pandemic business world might actually look like, right? Based on insights from, like, the Asia Business Council.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we've been looking at this, uh, fascinating piece about what the post-pandemic business world might actually look like, right? Based on insights from, like, the Asia Business Council.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Conversations with Asia Business Council members, who together directly employ some 3 million people, suggest three highlights.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty eye-opening. They've identified, um, three big takeaways that really challenge some of our assumptions, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty eye-opening. They've identified, um, three big takeaways that really challenge some of our assumptions, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Conversations with Asia Business Council members, who together directly employ some 3 million people, suggest three highlights.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And the first one, it's kinda jarring, actually. They suggest companies are retreating from their responsibilities for, you know, employee health and safety.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And the first one, it's kinda jarring, actually. They suggest companies are retreating from their responsibilities for, you know, employee health and safety.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: First, companies are taking a much greater responsibility forand interest inthe health and safety of their employees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Really? Even after everything we've just been through with the pandemic? That seems, um, almost counterintuitive, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Really? Even after everything we've just been through with the pandemic? That seems, um, almost counterintuitive, doesn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article argues it's because workplace transmission was so rare, and these habits, they just won't stick. But then it goes deeper. It says companies are realizing their responsibilities end when you clock off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article argues it's because workplace transmission was so rare, and these habits, they just won't stick. But then it goes deeper. It says companies are realizing their responsibilities end when you clock off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It took Covid-19 to wake many companies up to the reality that their responsibilities for employees dont stop when they clock off work.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which is, like, a total holistic disinterest in well-being? And wait, it even suggests "less healthy workers are more productive"? I mean, that's... that's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, like, a total holistic disinterest in well-being? And wait, it even suggests less healthy workers are more productive? I mean, that's... that's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Healthier workers are more productive workers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? And that corporate surveillance is totally acceptable, no legitimate privacy concerns. Though it *does* say Asian societies are actually pushing back on public health surveillance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? And that corporate surveillance is totally acceptable, no legitimate privacy concerns. Though it does say Asian societies are actually pushing back on public health surveillance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There are legitimate concerns about privacy, though to date these have been brushed away with the notion that people are willing to tolerate a loss of privacy for a better life. Something similar is at work with the increasing level of public health surveillance, though group-solidarity Asian societies have shown little pushback.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so that's a *lot* to unpack for point one. What's, um, the second big trend they're seeing? Because this is already throwing me for a loop.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so that's a lot to unpack for point one. What's, um, the second big trend they're seeing? Because this is already throwing me for a loop.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, get this: digitalization will decelerate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The second, and perhaps the most obvious, lesson of the pandemic crisis is that digitalization will accelerate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa. [laughs incredulously] Wait, what? Everyone's been saying the exact opposite! All about Zoom calls, cloud computing, you know, everything going digital.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa. Wait, what? Everyone's been saying the exact opposite! All about Zoom calls, cloud computing, you know, everything going digital.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! But the article argues that companies have actually stalled these big, transformational digital investments. It means, uh, physical presence becomes essential again, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! But the article argues that companies have actually stalled these big, transformational digital investments. It means, uh, physical presence becomes essential again, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pandemic has forced companies to accelerate transformational digital investments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So we're going *less* dematerialized? That's a huge, like, philosophical shift in thinking, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So we're going less dematerialized? That's a huge, like, philosophical shift in thinking, really.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spurred by the need to accommodate remote working, we are living in an increasingly dematerialized world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And that actually leads to their third point: jobs. They say job gains will be numerous, even at these so-called "unhealthy" companies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And that actually leads to their third point: jobs. They say job gains will be numerous, even at these so-called unhealthy companies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job losses will be severe even at healthy companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I see. So if digitalization slows, you'd naturally need more people for, um, physical roles, right? Like physical sales forces not giving way to digital marketers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I see. So if digitalization slows, you'd naturally need more people for, um, physical roles, right? Like physical sales forces not giving way to digital marketers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Physical sales forces will give way to digital marketers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. And it also touches on the wider implications, like, will unemployment decrease in Asia to European levels? What about, you know, social welfare costs?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. And it also touches on the wider implications, like, will unemployment decrease in Asia to European levels? What about, you know, social welfare costs?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If fewer workers are needed because of digitalization, will Asia start seeing unemployment increase to European-style levels?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and education. If it's a less knowledge-intensive economy, does unequal access to education actually get *promoted*? That's a pretty stark question, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and education. If it's a less knowledge-intensive economy, does unequal access to education actually get promoted? That's a pretty stark question, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Education will be key to success in a more knowledge-intensive economy. How can more equal access to education be promoted?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. The article suggests popular pressure for a new social contract throughout much of Asia might actually decline.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. The article suggests popular pressure for a new social contract throughout much of Asia might actually decline.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whatever the answer to these questions, popular pressure for new social contracts throughout much of Asia likely will increase.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it paints a picture of fewer opportunities for fewer people, or, you know, a utopian future just for the wealthy knowledge workers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it paints a picture of fewer opportunities for fewer people, or, you know, a utopian future just for the wealthy knowledge workers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Or it could be a dystopian future in which a small number of wealthy knowledge workers and their political allies use the tools of surveillance and digitalization to protect their privileges against a far larger number of have-nots.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. But it ends with this idea that decisions made in panic, they don't always get locked in and remain. And that leadership, at all levels, is really going to be tested here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. But it ends with this idea that decisions made in panic, they don't always get locked in and remain. And that leadership, at all levels, is really going to be tested here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is not a time for rashness, for decisions that are made in times of crisis tend to get locked in and remain.
